The work is challenging and you learn a lot, especially in your first 3 months. The amount I've experienced so far when it comes to the ins and outs of health administration on a finance aspect is unbeatable and whether I stay with MHS for my entire career lifespan or decide to move I know what I've gathered and learnt from my supervisor, colleagues, and other department workers will carry with me for my entire life.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Miramar, FL
pros: Good benefits (used to be better), tuition reimbursement, paid time off, clean and pretty facility.
cons: This company has changed so much ever since Sacco stepped down as President. It saddens me to see how little management cares for their nurses. We are putting our lives at risk and dealing with unsafe nurse-patient ratios, horrible short-staffing, and extremely short to no breaks on a daily basis. Even the travel nurses don’t want to come back. Sure, the hospital is pretty and you’ll get your warm blankets and juice, but the staff is neglected. I am completely against managers receiving an email every time an employee applies for another job within the system… all it leads to is passive aggressiveness and awkwardness… instead of the management wondering WHY the staff wants to leave. Sad to see how we are literally just machines expected to reach unrealistic expectations while at the same time allowing patients to treat us horribly without any intervening. Makes me (and many others) want to leave the profession.

job_title: Physical Therapist in Pembroke Pines, FL
pros:
- 1 on 1 PT to patient care for 45 minute sessions.
- They try to give you less than 2 evals a day. (which is still a lot to document especially when they're mixed in with progress reports and plan of cares)
- Management and employees are genuinely nice (but they still have to answer to people outside of patient care who's main concern is increasing profit in their pockets not yours even though you're the one working the hardest trying to meet their demands and expectations)
-They mandate the flu vaccine and I will not be surprised when they try to mandate the covid vaccine. You should no be required to provide a medical exemption or religious exemption to have a voice about what goes into you're own body. This just proves that they're the same as everyone else who have their own ties with politics and pharmaceutical companies. They say it's to keep the patients safe but that's marketing and a social guilt tactic.
cons:
- Poor compensation. (Below average)
-No documentation time you're expected to document while treating the patient. (If you're a practicing therapist you know how unrealistic this is when you're trying to provide quality pt care. They use EPIC and its a monster at consuming all your documentation time.
-It's all about productivity and $$$. It's only the illusion of patient care and employee satisfaction.
- Clinical ladder = small pay raise for more work when your schedule is already jammed
- Will cut your hours and mess with your schedule to boost their productivity
- Poor patient follow through with same therapist. They end up on 5 different PT schedules due to lack of availability on your schedule however your schedule is full of patients you have never seen before. Doesn't make sense.
- They say the benefits are great here but I don't see they're value.
- A lot of shuffling around paperwork and hurdles to jump through as management one being pt satisfaction surveys that we depend upon to get a small bonus at the end of the year.
-Styrofoam everything. Need to be more environmentally friendly.

review_title: Community Youth Counselor II (Dont do it if you value your Master's degree).
job_title: Community Youth Counselor II in Hollywood, FL
pros: The hospital itself is fantastic.  The benefits are incomparable.  The people in your actual team can be really cool.  Some programs will give you your own cubicle.  There are a lot of clients that you can actually help!
cons:
If you are looking for strictly one-on-one counseling opportunities, don't work here.  The turn over is ridiculously high because it's terrible there.  You are expected to transport clients (this can put you in scary situations) and to see them at all costs (even if they don't need or want to see you).  The management is aloof and NOT supportive.  This actually makes the work environment hostile (everyone there is miserable and unfriendly, and management is quick to write you up for any reason).  The hours are LONG and the management almost forces you to work late hours/weekends.  Paperwork and travel time is not factored into your 40 hours a week, so you will always struggle to complete documentation and you WILL get written up.
My particular program manager was terrible:  she NEVER trained me, and yet I was reprimanded by surprise when i did not meet subjective expectations.  I would be asked to cancel my scheduled client appointments almost weekly to do favors for my supervisor, and then I would get in trouble when I didn't see the clients.  I was treated as though I didn't have a degree.   These people are only preoccupied with making hours, even if they have to keep hiring people.

review_title: Good company but the over “budgeting” seems to help corporate more than the hospital staff.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hollywood, FL
pros:
Great coworkers
Great managers 
Yearly evaluations gives you an opportunity for a raise...until the cut off of course.
GREAT benefits
cons:
Lots of budget cuts since Frank left—has not seem to benefit the employees in any way.
No employee engagement of any sort (especially when needed most in an environment that is very easy to burn out)
If your department is short, you can be overworked during that period of time.
OVERLY strict attendance policy + UNREALISTIC sick policies...guess I’ll come in with my fever because I can’t afford the UA and since FMLA won’t protect my circumstances, I’ll be close to written up when I’m late due to my own or my child’s health issues. 
You can be very underpaid. The clerical positions are ridiculously underpaid. 
Old HR at Memorial Hospital West allowed for certain managers and directors to speak and treat their employees in whatever manner they wanted. When reported to HR, they would respond with “it’s all under the director’s discretion” in the friendliest demeanor or it would put shoved under a rug. Ever since the new HR staff has started, everything feels as if there is more of a human and equal approach to things and management has really become more warm.

review_title: Committed Employees and Leadership Team, Great Atmosphere!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pembroke Pines, FL
pros:
- Committed Employees and Leaders
- Very transparent organization
- Mission oriented. Everyone here is focused on the patient, even the non-clinical employees.
- Great atmosphere, very friendly - people are warm and genuine
- Supportive leadership
- Just Culture - people are not punished for making mistakes if their intentions were good.
- Committed to process and performance improvement. Always looking on ways to get better. Ideas are actively solicited from employees and acted upon.
- Advancement opportunities - Memorial is serious about offering opportunities to their employees. Many of the leaders have been promoted up through the ranks, so they know what it's like to be a front line employee.
- Development opportunities - tuition assistance at 100% of in state tuition rates can't be beat! Memorial also offers a lot of internal training.
- Leadership is open-minded and not afraid to try new things.
- Leadership has an open door policy and routinely creates avenues for employees to offer feedback, as well as hear directly from the top about everything from finances, marketplace changes, physicians, strategies, challenges, new services, etc.
- Benefit package (although recently changed) is still extremely competitive.
cons: - Being one of the smaller hospitals in the system, sometimes it feels like we don't get the same resources as the other locations.

job_title: Corporate Office in Miramar, FL
pros: They offer a lot of fringe benefits.
cons: I don’t even know where to begin. MHS stands by their values and the pillars of excellence yet I’ve never worked in a place where employees were so disrespectful to one another. I believe this only applies to the patients. Also, the pay grade is extremely low and they do not allow OT in certain departments because the department doesn’t bring in revenue. All departments are an important aspect to the success of the hospital, that’s why they exist. All the money goes to nursing. What the executive staff fails to understand is that the workload is nonstop and overwhelming. There is never any down time. I can compare it to being in timeout for 8 hours out of the day where you’re restricted to your desk that you can’t even use the restroom. It’s stressful when you have so much to do yet there is no flexibility, no OT, and management is breathing down your neck due to deadlines. MHS did not meet my expectations.

review_title: Overall good - some very bad management
job_title: Multiple Positions in Hollywood, FL
pros: Overall a family atmosphere, with opportunity to grow yourself through an amazing organizational team (shout out to Sergio!) Benefits are good, you know you will be paid.
cons: Management in some of the areas has been very poor. They started to clear out some of the hot pockets, but it needs to be looked at a lot closer. There are also others that self promote themselves while also keeping their friends close to assist in the process.

job_title: Insurance Billing in Miramar, FL
pros: There are some great nurses, compassionate people, and great benefits. Incentives are not comparable to any other company that I am aware of. Corporate free lunches for special occasions are very good. We receive an email everyday from the President that encourages the corporate culture, vision, and commends employees. Corporate culture is very important to me. Although it does not have a strong corporate culture, its there nonetheless.
cons: It saddens me to see such horrible reviews about management but I understand what the other reviewers are talking about. I work within the Memorial Support Services building. My own personal experience with management is equally just as bad as other reviewers. I stuck it out though and after a few years I tried applying to other departments because I found I was waking up everyday dreading to go to work. I've applied to a fair amount of positions within the company but when I check my resume submission status, within a day it shows as "not selected". I have outstanding reviews and there is no reason to not be able to move up in the company. With a Masters degree in the healthcare field., honors graduate, leadership experience, recommendations from managers at the prior company I worked for, and great internal reviews...why should I NOT be able to move up within the company? Had I known I was going to get hired in a dead-end job I would have respectfully declined job offer. I believe the problem is when an employee applies for another position within the company, your director and/or manager are notified. Believe me, I have suffered the passive aggressive consequences of trying to better myself by applying for other internal jobs. The comments I get from management are unprofessional and extremely rude. There are people within my department who are very unhappy so they feel the need to make other people miserable. We are discouraged from using any teamwork or collaboration. We are discouraged for thinking outside the box,.having an opinion, or having/doing anything that other employers would look at as a great quality. I feel as though I am a factory worker in an assembly line. We just do our job and keep everything moving. So in a nutshell, the cons are the lack of growth (dead end jobs), poor management, unrewarding emotionally and mentally.

review_title: Love the company, not the supervisors
job_title: Patient Transporter in Hollywood, FL
pros: The way Memorial Regional operates is wonderful. I love what they stand for and the care that they provide to all of their patients. They hire great staff and do things pretty efficiently. One of the main reasons why I loved going to work (besides having the opportunity to help people) is to be with my fantastic coworkers.
cons:
The supervisors in the transportation department did some pretty unfair things to the employees. For example, they would only hire "per-diem" workers to speed up the hiring process and avoid giving benefits yet make the employees work just as much as a part-time (or even full-time) employee. The official process of per-diem is to call whenever a full or part-time employee cannot go into work and that employee fills in the gaps. However, in the transport department, per-diem employees were scheduled like any other employee with no flexibility to their schedule. In my opinion, it was extremely difficult to switch or ask for time off, even though I was not technically supposed to be on the schedule to begin with. I think this process is just a way for the hospital to save money? But that's only a guess on my part.

Also, salary-wise: $10.25 is not nearly enough for the exposure patient transporters have with patients. Management argues that it isn't a "patient contact job," yet what have I been doing all day? Lifting patients, assisting PCAs, CNAs, technicians, and nurses do their jobs, and I am responsible for their life while they are solely in my care? And if they are on a telemetry pack, I am responsible that it is being read correctly by the monitor technician? $10.25 is petty. A person folding clothes at a mature women's apparel store makes that much without that sort of responsibility.

This job is very physically demanding. It's pretty much hard labor in medical form. Future employees must consider whether pushing a 100 lb bed with a 300 lb person on top across the hospital is right for them. This job is not for the faint of heart (or body). Also, at this specific location, management demands efficiency. So sitting for a minute between patients is nearly impossible. The end result if you do? Write-up. they track your whereabouts like a hawk.

Transferring from this department to others is way too difficult. I know several coworkers of mine who had nursing degrees and ACTUAL JOBS with Memorial but the supervisors would not release them from the department.

If these cons don't seem terrible to you, then by all means, go for it.

cons:
-Old fashioned mentality still pervades the organization. Salaried corporate employees still need to clock in-clock out. Very political.  
-I was unlucky to fall under a Director who managed by fear and intimidation, in typical 50's command and control style. This person was unable to delegate and trust his direct reports to do their jobs and created an oppressive and negative atmosphere, micro-managing everyone. He would frequency berate and badmouth his direct reports in front of other employees, and caused several talented people to quit. I have worked in the IT industry for more than 20 years (many of those in healthcare) and I have never seen anything like this. People complained about him but nothing happened. He seemed to be untouchable because he was brought in by the VP of IT (who seemed like a good guy though). 
-I also witnessed another manager (also brought in by the same VP of IT) verbally abuse her direct reports several times.  
-Mediocre benefits. Health insurance plans only includes their health system as in-network. PTO could be better. No Short-Term Disability (have to buy independently).

job_title: Retired From Paoli Hospital Safety and Security Department in Indiana, PA
pros: I retired in 2015 after almost 40 to the day years of service at Paoli Hospital. For those seeking positions and a career in the security department I would  recommend it.  It was  a "never a dull moment" type atmosphere.. The campus , a Level 2 Trauma Center , is one of the best in the nation in my opinion. Your daily routine is composed of  random foot and mobile patrol of the campus , securing the helipad landing zone for incoming helicopters and assisting the flight crew down into the trauma bays with patients. Add that  to the duties  of securing sensitive areas ,  responding to emergency situations ,  monitoring the CCTV and alarms in the state of the art Dispatch Center just to name a few. The staff to work  with are great along with a great security director. Pay and benefits are excellent and may I mention the pension is pretty good. Remember, if hired you may the first impression a visitor, staff or patient comes away with.  There is plenty of interaction with public.Remember you are also a public relations officer in the role of security officer at Paoli Hospital. Do great job and good luck !
cons: Weekend coverage may be an issue for some but that is the nature of working in healthcare. But you will get used to it and it is nice to have days off during the week.

review_title: Great magnet hospital with tiny downfalls
job_title: Staff Nurse RN in Bryn Mawr, PA
pros: Working for a Magnet Hospital has it perks and there is a strong sense of feeling appreciated and being cared about as an employee. Only here PRN on the off tours, I have enjoyed multiple complimentary meals and have even met the Chief Nursing Officer, all things that I have never accomplished at my other job working full time for the past 5 years.
cons: Mainline Health strives for all of their nurses to excel, however; only provides educational opportunities or tuition reimbursement to their full time employees. There are so many changes that occur on a daily basis and clear communication to all disciplines of staff is difficult resulting in many surprises, desirable or not. No raises to PRN staff despite having to complete all the required elements that full time staff do (reviews, etc.).

job_title: Phlebotomist/Senior Laboratory Assistant in Bryn Mawr, PA
pros: I worked for main line health for 14 years. I have many physical disabilities. They were always willing to work with me. I was on Family Leave Act for the last three years I was there. And they never gave me a hard time. My pay raises were pretty darn good. Of course they do not compare to what you would get working in the city but for the suburbs it was compatible.
cons: I had difficulty with management as far as trying to get a problem resolved. They definitely had favorites and it shouldn't be that way especially in a hospital. I do think it was a downfall when they started calling patients clients it gave a whole new atmosphere to the hospital atmosphere I don't think it was for the good.

review_title: They do not value their staff, only money
job_title: Former Staff Nurse in Wynnewood, PA
pros: Most days off approved by managers, pay is good.  Financial problems brought on by bad moves like building a huge ED and the Heart Pavilion a few years ago.  There has to be patients to fill them with.  They just close units to compensate.
cons: Management are puppets to the higher level of administration which doesn't help the nurses.  Dangerous nurse/patient ratios.  They closed half of the observation unit and there were no other jobs posted.  Oh well, time to find another job.  Mandatory down staffing  makes it hard to feed your family.  Staff education is a low priority.  Most departments are really overworked and stretched to their limits.

review_title: Nice company objectives from the outside, but various components are broken on the inside.
job_title: Network Field Engineer in Bryn Mawr, PA
pros: Nice health benefits, vacation plans, and pension.
cons: 1. I rarely see any African American nurses around, maybe they have them all hidden on the night shifts. So, if you are African American, don't expect to be a nurse here.  2. The management in the IS department doesn't seem to care about communication. We rarely hear from our Director, we barely hear from our Manager, and our direct supervisor is hardly at his desk and loves to work remotely from home (he forwards his office calls to his cell phone). review_title: Large Hulking IT Structure with a small onsite footprint
